awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Advanced Technologies for HYpersonic, Propulsive, Energetic, and Reusable Platforms (HYPER)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site: Advanced Technologies for Hypersonic, Propulsive, Energetic and Reusable Platforms (HYPER) at the University of Central Florida (UCF) addresses challenges in next-generation modes of transportation and energy generation. Realizing planned platforms for advanced space travel and energy production can only be achieved through multidisciplinary research. This REU site will actively recruit and partner a diverse group of approximately 33 students over 3 years with leading faculty and graduate students at UCF. Together, these teams will advance the fundamental knowledge needed to overcome technical barriers limiting hypersonic flight. Candidate REU students will be matched with individual research projects based on their interests and skills. With the majority of their time engaged in cutting-edge research, REU students will also benefit from research-oriented seminars, professional development workshops, software training, and launch pad facility tours. HYPER has several goals; most importantly, to prepare students for PhD-level research and research-oriented employment.

HYPER will cultivate and unite multidisciplinary interests to study advanced structures and systems with application to hypersonics, space, propulsion, and energy. For example, components in launch vehicles are subjected to combined extreme environments where fluid-structure interactions are key considerations. Also, advanced manufacturing must be better understood to improve component performance and reduce weight. Frameworks for modeling digital versions of systems must be created to predict overall performance more accurately. Participants will gain hands-on research training in contemporary challenges such as: (1) utilizing advanced manufacturing techniques for high-value components, (2) integrating in situ monitoring of stress- strain evolution, (3) developing novel methods for improved internal cooling and heat transfer effectiveness, (4) mitigating flutter through advanced rotor dynamic control, etc. Eleven modules are crafted to engage students in PhD-level topics; these research topics rely on approaches that cut across disciplines and techniques (e.g., experiments and simulations). As a result, HYPER will play a key role in preparing a workforce of young engineers and scientists for research careers in these areas.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site: HYPER at the University of Central Florida (UCF) provided highly appropriate research-oriented experiences to 33 students funded by NSF resources and 9 more funded through other sources (42 total students) over 3 years. Students engaged in 11 distinct research projects conducted in various College of Engineering and Computer Science (CECS) laboratories. Many of these challenges rely on approaches that cut across disciplines and research techniques (e.g., experiments and simulations). HYPER sought to cultivate and unite multidisciplinary interests to study advanced structures and systems with application to hypersonics, space, propulsion, and energy. The research experiences were unique for several reasons: (1) each faculty mentor already was engaged in high-level research with federal, state, and industrial sponsors; (2) the PIs curated projects with focused topics that combined to deliver holistic coverage of hypersonics, propulsion, and reusable platforms; and (3) UCF’s bent for partnering with local industry imbued contemporary aerospace/defense challenges into the research activities.

The REU Site: HYPER convened for the summers of 2019, 2021, and 2022. Limited housing options and social distancing requirements imposed at UCF during the initial spread of COVID-19 rendered HYPER impractical in 2020. Not including 2020, HYPER attracted 1,400 applications. Each summer’s applicant pool was national in terms of university representation, diverse in terms of prior experiences and undergraduate major, and diverse in terms of demographics. Each summer, the site attracted a strong participant pool facilitated by a strong applicant pool that in turn was generated from a collaborative approach to marketing and communications. The site projected a cohort comprised of at least 80% females or students from underrepresented minority groups; approximately 81% was achieved. The site sought to include at most seven participants from UCF (about two per year). This metric was achieved in the first (2019) and last (2022) summers. During the second COVID summer (2021), HYPER included four UCF students to enable achievement of other program outcomes. Although not a stated goal of the site, 64% of the cohort hailed from universities with research activities more limited than those available at UCF. 

Research outcomes from the prior site demonstrate HYPER’s effectiveness in changing students’ skills / attitudes about research, graduate school, and more. Per external evaluation (PEER) pre- and post-experience surveys, “Research Self Efficacy” improved from 3.5/5.0 to 4.5/5.0. Providing formal ANSYS training, conducting industry site tours, and experiencing rocket launches and landings firsthand improved attitudes about interdisciplinary research and students’ role in contributing to future technology. Post-program surveys reveal 100% of participants either agreed or strongly agreed that their experiences in HYPER were satisfactory. More information about program outcomes appears in peer-reviewed articles presented in various venues by the PIs, as well as through student-authored conference/journal publications on their specific research projects with their faculty mentors. 

Throughout the REU Site: HYPER, the PIs have sought to amplify the site’s impact by leveraging third-party funds to support additional participants and enhance the program activities. In 2021 and 2022, several external institutions, as well as HYPER faculty members, facilitated support to include greater participation. These students were subject to identical standards/benefits as NSF/DoD-funded HYPER students (i.e., same application process, reporting requirements, stipend level). Nine extra students were able to participate with no cost to NSF/DoD. 

UCF plays a key role in preparing a workforce of young scientists for research careers in these areas. This REU Site further strengthened bridges between UCF and the technical community, as well as institutions with limited research capabilities. The site actively engaged women and underrepresented participants by way of recruitment partners (AAP, CECS Office of Diversity and Inclusion). Each student participant received professional development training in the form of workshops for scientific writing and PhD program application development. HYPER participants communicated their research activities and advances to their communities via posters, presentations, written reports, and conference/archival publications. The REU Site: HYPER investigated the effect of exposing participants to various disciplines required to achieve next-generation flight and turbomachinery and studied how seeing research realized in systems impacts participants’ self-efficacy.


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Jeffrey L Kauffman
